title: Power Density by Generation Technology

source.agency: U.S. Department of Energy / National Renewable Energy Laboratory
source.dataset: Land-Use Requirements for Solar Power Plants in the United States & Wind Energy Land Use Synthesis

caveats: Power density = average generation divided by total land area used. Higher is more land-efficient.
Wind power density uses total lease area including spacing; direct footprint is much smaller.
Solar values represent utility-scale ground-mounted installations; rooftop solar uses no additional land.
Nuclear and fossil values include the power plant, fuel handling, and buffer zones but not mining/extraction land.
Ranges reflect variation across sites, technologies, and capacity factors.
Hydro values vary enormously depending on reservoir size relative to dam capacity.
